ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course is great. Professor Kooris provides an honest look at urban planning as profession and historical exercise.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Real world perspective.
Hearing from a practitioner in the field was very helpful.
I liked the free-form nature of the instructor's interaction with the class. Aside from the syllabus, he brings real world experience into the classroom and this is an invaluable asset.
David is a practitioner himself and brings a lot of real works perspectives.

Professor Kooris has a great perspective to teach this course because of his past and current professional planning experience. I felt like I learned a lot from him and that his class is integral to the land use curriculum at F&ES.
David Kooris.
The final project is an excellent way to do anything you want. Very flexible and open opportunity.
Professor Kooris has experience in both the private and public sector side of urban planning.
The in-class discussions and seminar style are very helpful and make the class more valuable to students.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The readings were not always uploaded on time. Even though the readings weren't always directly referred to in class, I appreciated having them under my belt in advance to round out my understanding of concepts. That said, it would have been nice if they were available in a timely manner.
Sometimes it just felt like the class ran very long; I don't think it's an issue with the professor or material, but maybe because it is held in the evening around dinnertime.
I think it would be better if it wasn't taught it one 3hr chunk. Hard to keep focus for that long even with a break.
Lectures could be more organized and important elements delivered in a more structured way.
Assignment feedback. I had no idea what my grade was going into the final paper. I am a little worried right now.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussion flowed freely throughout each class, but sometimes the lack of structure was frustrating. For example, it could take a long time for the lecture to start because tangential discussion would take place at the beginning of class. This is not to say that these conversations weren't interesting, just not as structured as I would have liked.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It provides a look at the American planning and development framework and is a great reference point.

I thought this provided a great basis for learning about land use planning. Professor Kooris brings a wealth of experience from his previous job at RPA and his current position in Bridgeport, so not only is he qualified to teach the basics of planning policy, but he also gives great insight into what it is like to really do it.
Will help me get involved in open lands conservation and regional planning. Possibly set me up for a planning degree or profession.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to improve my planning knowledge.
I came to F&ES to concentrate in land use and planning to supplement my future career in land use law. This course fit perfectly with my goals.
To gain exposure to the material, not for the learning environment or for the teaching.
I'm interested in urban planning and property development, and the undergraduate curriculum lacks classes in those areas.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Yes.

Yes, it actually exceeded my expectations. Not only did we cover all the basics as well as current trends in sustainable development/resiliency, but we also got great insights into the practical, everyday aspects of working in municipal government.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings - they make the in-class discussions and lectures more valuable and interesting.
Have a project in mind, and actively engage the instructor on it so you can shape the learning to your specific needs.
Take this course if you are interested in urban planning! If you haven't worked in government, you will learn a lot about how it functions in post industrial cities. That is invaluable.
